sections.summary: The DXY measures the value of the US Dollar relative to a basket of foreign currencies (Euro, Yen, Pound, etc.). It acts as the 'Wrecking Ball' for global asset/risk prices.
sections.deep_dive: When DXY rises, global liquidity tightens. Emerging markets suffer (dollar-denominated debt gets harder to pay), commodities fall (priced in dollars), and US corporate earnings (multinationals) take a hit due to currency conversion.
sections.council_debate: {"geopolitics": "The weaponization of the dollar (sanctions) is driving BRICS nations to trade in local currencies. Long term, this weakens the structural bid for USD. Short term, in a crisis, everyone still runs to the dollar.", "macro": "The 'Dollar Smile Theory': The dollar rises in a US Boom (strong growth) AND in a Global Bust (safety). It falls only when the US muddles along while the Rest of World grows faster.", "quant": "Strong negative correlation with Bitcoin and Gold. A break below 100 signals the start of the 'Reflation Phase'.", "policy": "Yellen is engaging in stealth intervention (Treasury buybacks) to keep the dollar from spiking too high, which would break the US bond market. sections.forecast_risks: The 'De-dollarization' tail risk. If Saudi Arabia prices oil in Yuan fully, or if a competing BRICS reserve currency gains traction, the DXY could collapse structurally, causing hyper-inflation in the US (import prices soar).
sections.gms_conclusion: The ultimate gauge of global stress. If DXY is rising, liquidity is falling. We prefer a DXY trending down toward 98 for a Broad-Based Bull Market.
